description: Uncertain. Perhaps from Yiddish חבֿר‎ (khaver, “friend, comrade”), from Hebrew חבר‎ (khavér, “friend”), possibly via Dutch gabber, perhaps from the British dialectal term cob (“take a liking to”).., or a conflation of both. The suggestion that it is a self-referential collective term for convicts and immigrants who departed for Australian shores from the Irish port of Cobh seems chronologically unlikely.

entries.meaning: (Australia) A pal, buddy, mate, friend; often used in direct address by one male to another.
(Australia) A sweet consisting of a small block of hard caramel covered in chocolate.
